briefdescription.para: Guess the file type for an N-Gram model from the filename.

simplesect.para: the guessed file type, or NGRAM_INVALID if none could be guessed.

briefdescription.para: Get the N-Gram file type from a string.

simplesect.para: file type, or NGRAM_INVALID if no such file type exists.

briefdescription.para: Get the canonical name for an N-Gram file type.

simplesect.para: read-only string with the name for this file type, or NULL if no such type exists.

briefdescription.para: Read an N-Gram model from a file on disk.

parameterdescription.para: Optional pointer to a set of command-line arguments. Recognized arguments are:

listitem.para: -lw (float32) language weight to apply to the model
-wip (float32) word insertion penalty to apply to the model

parameterdescription.para: path to the file to read.
type of the file, or NGRAM_AUTO to determine automatically.

Log-math parameters to use for probability calculations. Ownership of this object is assumed by the newly created ngram_model_t, and you should not attempt to free it manually. If you wish to reuse it elsewhere, you must retain it with logmath_retain().

briefdescription.para: Write an N-Gram model to disk.

memberdef.name: ngram_model_init

briefdescription.para: Initialize the base ngram_model_t structure.
Retain ownership of an N-Gram model.
Flush any cached N-Gram information.
Release memory associated with an N-Gram model.

simplesect.para: new reference count (0 if freed completely)

briefdescription.para: Case-fold word strings in an N-Gram model.

detaileddescription.para: WARNING: This is not Unicode aware, so any non-ASCII characters will not be converted.

briefdescription.para: Apply a language weight, insertion penalty, and unigram weight to a language model.

detaileddescription.para: This will change the values output by ngram_score() and friends. This is done for efficiency since in decoding, these are the only values we actually need. Call ngram_prob() if you want the "raw" N-Gram probability estimate.
To remove all weighting, call ngram_apply_weights(model, 1.0, 1.0).

briefdescription.para: Get the current weights from a language model.

parameterdescription.para: Output: (optional) logarithm of word insertion penalty.

memberdef.argsstring: (ngram_model_t *model, int32 wid, int32 *history, int32 n_hist, int32 *n_used)
memberdef.name: ngram_ng_score

briefdescription.para: Quick general N-Gram score lookup.
Get the score (scaled, interpolated log-probability) for a general N-Gram.

detaileddescription.para: The argument list consists of the history words (as null-terminated strings) of the N-Gram, in reverse order, followed by NULL. Therefore, if you wanted to get the N-Gram score for "a whole joy", you would call:

This is not the function to use in decoding, because it has some overhead for looking up words. Use ngram_ng_score(), ngram_tg_score(), or ngram_bg_score() instead. In the future there will probably be a version that takes a general language model state object, to support suffix-array LM and things like that.

If one of the words is not in the LM's vocabulary, the result will depend on whether this is an open or closed vocabulary language model. For an open-vocabulary model, unknown words are all mapped to the unigram <UNK> which has a non-zero probability and also participates in higher-order N-Grams. Therefore, you will get a score of some sort in this case.

For a closed-vocabulary model, unknown words are impossible and thus have zero probability. Therefore, if word is unknown, this function will return a "zero" log-probability, i.e. a large negative number. To obtain this number for comparison, call ngram_zero().

memberdef.argsstring: (ngram_model_t *model, int32 w3, int32 w2, int32 w1, int32 *n_used)
memberdef.name: ngram_tg_score

briefdescription.para: Quick trigram score lookup.
Quick bigram score lookup.

memberdef.argsstring: (ngram_model_t *model, int32 wid, int32 *history, int32 n_hist, int32 *n_used)
memberdef.name: ngram_ng_prob

briefdescription.para: Quick "raw" probability lookup for a general N-Gram.

detaileddescription.para: See documentation for ngram_ng_score() and ngram_apply_weights() for an explanation of this.

briefdescription.para: Get the "raw" log-probability for a general N-Gram.

detaileddescription.para: This returns the log-probability of an N-Gram, as defined in the language model file, before any language weighting, interpolation, or insertion penalty has been applied.

simplesect.para: When backing off to a unigram from a bigram or trigram, the unigram weight (interpolation with uniform) is not removed.

briefdescription.para: Get the "raw" log-probability for a general N-Gram.

detaileddescription.para: This returns the log-probability of an N-Gram, as defined in the language model file, before any language weighting, interpolation, or insertion penalty has been applied.

simplesect.para: When backing off to a unigram from a bigram or trigram, the unigram weight (interpolation with uniform) is not removed.

briefdescription.para: Convert score to "raw" log-probability.

simplesect.para: The unigram weight (interpolation with uniform) is not removed, since there is no way to know which order of N-Gram generated score.

parameterdescription.para: The N-Gram model from which score was obtained.

briefdescription.para: Get the unknown word ID for a language model.

detaileddescription.para: Language models can be either "open vocabulary" or "closed vocabulary". The difference is that the former assigns a fixed non-zero unigram probability to unknown words, while the latter does not allow unknown words (or, equivalently, it assigns them zero probability). If this is a closed vocabulary model, this function will return NGRAM_INVALID_WID.

simplesect.para: The ID for the unknown word, or NGRAM_INVALID_WID if none exists.

briefdescription.para: Get the "zero" log-probability value for a language model.
Get the order of the N-gram model (i.e.

Add a word (unigram) to the language model.

simplesect.para: The semantics of this are not particularly well-defined for model sets, and may be subject to change. Currently this will add the word to all of the submodels

parameterdescription.para: The model to add a word to.
Text of the word to add.
Weight of this word relative to the uniform distribution.

simplesect.para: The word ID for the new word.

memberdef.name: ngram_model_add_class

briefdescription.para: Add a new class to a language model.

detaileddescription.para: If classname already exists in the unigram set for model, then it will be converted to a class tag, and classweight will be ignored. Otherwise, a new unigram will be created as in ngram_model_add_word().

briefdescription.para: Get the in-class log probability for a word in an N-Gram class.

simplesect.para: This probability, or 1 if word not found.

briefdescription.para: Read a probdef file.

inbodydescription.para: < Are we currently reading a list of class words?

briefdescription.para: Free a class definition.
Read a class definition file and add classes to a language model.

detaileddescription.para: This function assumes that the class tags have already been defined as unigrams in the language model. All words in the class definition will be added to the vocabulary as special in-class words. For this reason is is necessary that they not have the same names as any words in the general unigram distribution. The convention is to suffix them with ":class_tag", where class_tag is the class tag minus the enclosing square brackets.
